#JavaScript cheatsheet

Variables

Old way

var name = 'Jeppe';
var age = 10:

ES6

// if value stays constant
const name = 'Jeppe';
// if value can change later
let age = 10;

Functions

Really old way (unless you want to add method to class)

function myFunction(param1, param2) {
  // do something... 
}

Old way

var myFunction = function(param1, param2) {
  // do something...
}

ES6

const myFunction = (param1, param2) => {
  // do something...
}

Selecting HTML elements

<p id="btn">Click me!</p>

const element = document.querySelector('#btn');

Event handling

Really old way

<p onclick="// do something...">Click me!</p>

Old way

element.onclick = function(evt){
  // do something...
};

ES6

element.addEventListener('click',  (evt) => {
  // do something...
});

AJAX get method

Old way

const xhr = new XMLHttpRequest();
xhr.open('get', 'someJsonResponseServlet');
xhr.onreadystatechange = function(){
   if (xhr.readyState == 4 && xhr.status == 200) {
         const result = JSON.parse(xhr.responseText);
         console.log(result);
      }
}
xhr.send();

New way

fetch('someJsonResponseServlet')
  .then( (response) => {
    return response.json();
  })
  .then( (result) => {
    console.log(result);
  });

AJAX post method

Old way

// get data from e.g. form
const myForm = document.querySelector('form');
const fData = new FormData(myForm);
const xhr = new XMLHttpRequest();
xhr.open('post', 'someJsonResponseServlet');
xhr.onreadystatechange = function(){
   if (xhr.readyState == 4 && xhr.status == 200) {
         const result = JSON.parse(xhr.responseText);
         console.log(result);
      }
}
xhr.send(fData);

New way

// get data from e.g. form
const myForm = document.querySelector('form');
const fData = new FormData(lomake);
// asetusobjekti fetchi√§ varten 
const settings = {
  method: 'post',
  data: fData
};
fetch('someJsonResponseServlet', asetukset)
  .then( (response) => {
    return response.json();
  })
  .then( (result) => {
    console.log(result);
  });
